tn.text: "Keilah" is the name of a town. Here "Keilah" represents the people who live there. AT: "fighting against the people of Keilah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
separating the grain or seeds, generally from a cereal plant or wheat by some mechanical means

tn.ref: How much more then if we go to Keilah against the armies of the Philistines?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "We will be even more fearful if we go to Keilah to fight the armies of the Philistines." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The writer pays the most attention to David, so these words are all singular, though David's men helped him do all these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is the name of a man. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:21:01|21:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This can be translated in active form. AT: "Someone told Saul" or "They told Saul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"called for" or "assembled"
"David asked" or "David prayed" (UDB)

tn.ref: your servant has indeed heard ... as your servant has heard ... tell your servant
tn.text: David speaks as if he were someone else to show his respect for Yahweh. AT: "I have indeed heard ... as I have heard ... tell me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
Here "hand" represents power or control. AT: "give me over to Saul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"defeat completely"
or "David asked" or "David prayed" (UDB)

tn.ref: surrender me and my men into the hand of Saul
tn.text: Here "hand" represents power or control. AT: "give me and my men over to Saul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"600" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This can be translated in active form. AT: "Someone told Saul" or "They told Saul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"had run away from"
This is the name of a deserted area near the city of Ziph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: did not give him into his hand
tn.text: The word "hand" is a metonymy for power. AT: "did not allow Saul to have power over David" or "did not allow Saul to do as he desired with David" or "did not allow Saul to capture David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom. AT: "try to kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is the name of city near Ziph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is an idiom. AT "encouraged him to trust in God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: For the hand of Saul my father will not find you
tn.text: Here "hand" is a metonym for Saul and his power. AT: "For Saul my father will not find you" or "For Saul my father will never be able to have power over you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of the people group from Ziph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Is not David hiding among us in ... Jeshimon?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as an exclamation. AT: "David is hiding among us in ... Jeshimon!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is the name of a hill in the wilderness of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a desert area near the Dead Sea. It can also be translated as "the Judean Wilderness" or "the wasteland." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: surrender him into the king's hand
tn.text: The word "hand" is a metonym for power. The Ziphites speak to Saul as if he were another man to show him that they respect him. AT: "give David to you so you can do whatever you desire with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: May you be blessed by Yahweh
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "I hope that Yahweh blesses you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: you have had compassion on me
tn.text: "you have told this to me" (See UDB)
These two words mean almost the same thing and can be translated as one phrase. AT: "Know for sure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"who saw him"
This can be translated in active form. AT: "People tell me" or "I have heard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: among all the thousands of Judah
tn.text: This is an idiom. AT: "even if I have to arrest every man in Judah" or "among all the clans of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
They stopped what they had been doing. The reader should not believe that they were sitting or lying.
"Then the Ziphites"
This is the name of a place. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:23:13|23:14]].

This is the name of a desert area near the Dead Sea. It can also be translated as "the Judean Wilderness" or "the wasteland." Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:23:19|23:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This can be translated in active form. AT: "Someone told David that they were coming" or "David learned that they were coming" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
a hill covered with many rocks or boulders
This is the name of the deserted area around the city of Maon in southern Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The words "hurry" and "come" can be combined into one idea. AT: "Come quickly" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])
"chasing" or "following in order to catch"
a memorial or marker of David's escape from Saul
